parcel.name: Center for Collaborative Investigative Journalism (CCIJ)
parcel.description:
We are a nonprofit media organization that convenes and leads global investigations grounded in strategic mentorship.

We are committed to developing a model of collaborative journalism that holds compelling visual images, deep investigative reporting and data science as equal partners in producing a unique brand of storytelling focusing on underrepresented communities.ccij.io

features.text: the CCIJ + Oculardelusion and Y0b built
the first exhibition on this parcel in 2021.

features.id: The tools that Gogo Sarah Masaiwana uses to deliver babies in her home in kwaMapfunde, in Marange. She has delivered over 450 babies from 1998 and says none have died in her care. Photograph by Cynthia R Matonhodze / CCIJ

features.text:
Nyamadzawo Village in Marange.

 Photograph by Cynthia R Matonhodze / CCIJ

A portrait of St Noah hanging next to one of President Emmerson Mnangagwa in the pavillion of St Noah High School soccer field. President Mnangagwa has addressed members of the Johanne Marange Apostolic Church in this field on numerous occasions. 

 Photograph by Cynthia R Matonhodze / CCIJ

Beauty Chimuti (29) was married at the age of 14 to her husband who is now 85 years old. She is a member of the Johanne Marange Apostolic Sect and was raised by her uncle and aunt from the age of 7.

"I always regret not having a chance to finish school.". 

Photograph by Cynthia R Matonhodze / CCIJ

Rose (Sifelani Dukwende) is a former child bride who was married at 16 to a 43 year old man who had two other wives. She with her two children due to physical and financial abuse. She now works to take care of herself and her children. 

Photograph by Cynthia R Matonhodze / CCIJ

Gogo Sarah Masaiwana (55) is a lay midwife in the church and has delivered over 450 babies since she started in 1998, she claims there have been no deaths. She says most of the people she has helped are underage girls from the age of 12. "Its God's work so with God's work it happens on its own. No one has ever died in my care." 

Photograph by Cynthia R Matonhodze / CCIJ

A portrait of Sibongile Mukwananzi (42) who is an advocate against child marriages in her neighborhood in Nyamadzawo Village. "I got married at 16 when I was only in form 3. I spoiled my life for myself so it hurts me that my child seems to be following in my footsteps. 

Photograph by Cynthia R Matonhodze / CCIJ
